message: Shutter Island. What an odd choice of film for Scorsese to have signed on for.
The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (finally!). Wonderful.
Indocine(1991) brilliant french movie set on the 1950's on a rubber plantation.
Oh, goodie, someone agrees.

Rise of the Planet of the Apes of the Etc (which I got to see for free). Well made, with some pretty impressive action sequences and effects (see: Andy Serkis as compelling CG character), but it's tough to get over the hokey premise. It doesn't help that nearly every human in the movie is a walking, talking cliché. 

Oh, the scientific research boss who ONLY cares about the bottom line? And the guy who mistreats animals for no reason other than to build up resentment from the audience, who then cheers when he's inevitably killed? Please, tell me more.

Planet of the Apes films haven't been the same since the Simpsons Planet of the Apes: the Musical! episode (I hate every monkey, from chimpan-a to chimpan-zee) ...that said I liked the film. The stereotyped humans bothered me a little, but not that much.

@Neilan As a long parade of Hitchcock references, Shutter Island is exactly the right sort of film for Scorsese, who owes so much to Hitchcock in terms of style and technique (although not subject matter).

Oh, nice insight. It's the dissimilar subject matter that completely threw me.

Also the being bad bit.
Watched all but the season finale of Falling Skies. A fairly enjoyable sci-fi series. Now, where's my Walking Dead season 2?

Conan the Barbarian is really, really bad. Let's leave aside the pantomime level 'acting' and the awful script...the continuity is often so bad that the film simply does not make sense a lot of the time. Do people not notice this stuff any more or does no one care as long there's enough CGI?
What I want to know here is exactly how many bladed weapons fly out at the audience?

The 3D is fairly restrained, actually. By no means the worse post-production hack job I have seen (that would still be Crap of the Titans). But it's the usual problem of the action scenes looking indistinct in 3D - espeically the night time sequences. Action does NOT work in 3D, dark scenes do NOT work in 3D. I
@Mr_V Nope. But he is making a movie with Arnold Schwarzenegger. He will play Mozart. And Ahnuld will be Bach.
But will Jason Momoa be Governor one day?
Another movie that was kinda dissapointing, was Cowboys and Aliens.
Darn. I was not expecting Conan to be a good movie, but I was hoping for a guilty pleasure.
(That joke still cracks me up).

Oh? I thought Cowboys & Aliens was solid. I can't understand why critics adore Planet of the Apes (which is silly, has good effects and awful characters), but dislike C&A (which is silly, has good effects and good characters). Okay, sure, Harrison Ford is mostly terrible in it, but I thought it was a fun and surprisingly restrained blend of Western, horror and rescue film. 

Also, Clancy Brown is in it. CLANCY BROWN.

I don't feel like I wasted my money on it, but from the trailers I got the feeling it would be quite over the top, and then as you say, it ended up being quite restrained. I also never had any strong feelings regarding any of the main characters.

I should've learnt my lesson by now, and stop setting my expectations based on trailers though.

Your Highness: avoid unless you crave an hour and a half of f-bombs and dick jokes. Just can't help to feel that they could've toned down the vulgarity in favour of more subtle jokes (which there were tons of opportunity for).
Ugh, Your Highness was SO bad.
I still need to see Cowboys and Aliens. :\
